The Mango Birth Story
“In the past you ate my mangoes,
small and large, O celibate one;

analyzed: tehā iva mantehi na dāni tuyha
translated: With those very spells, I won’t give them to you now,
the fruits of the tree appear, O brahmin.”
“I honor the conjunction of the stars,
I don’t see the moment or the instant in the spells;
Having obtained the conjunction of the stars and the moment,
I will surely take many fruits.”
“In the past you didn’t speak of the conjunction of the stars,
in the past you didn’t announce the moment or the instant;
You yourself took many mango fruits,
endowed with color, smell, and taste.
By reciting the spells in the past,
the fruits of the tree appeared, O brahmin;
But today you can’t even recite the spell,

original: Ayaṁ so ko nāma tavajja dhammo”.
analyzed: ayam saḥ kaḥ nāma tavajja dhammaḥ
translated: what is this dharma of yours now?”
“The son of a caṇḍāla gave me,
by dharma, the spells and the natural abilities;
But don’t ask me about my name and clan,
if asked, the spell may abandon its meaning.
I was asked by the lord of the people in the midst of the people,
Overcome by conceit I spoke a lie:
‘These are the brahmin’s mantras,’ wrongly,
I am poor, without mantras, I weep.”
“The castor-oil plant, the puchimaṇḍa,
or the pālibhaddaka,
The honey-hunter finds honey,
that is the best of trees.
The noble, the brahmin, the merchant,
the worker, the outcast, the scavenger,
From whom one may know the Dhamma,
that is the best of men.
Having given him punishment and death,
and having seized him by the neck, you should beat the wretch;
He who has gained the highest good through striving,
has destroyed it through conceit and over-weening pride.”
“As one who thinks it is level might fall,
into the swamp, the cave, the hell, the putrid pool;
Or as one who steps on a rope might tread on a black snake,
as a blind man might set out on a journey;

analyzed: evam pi mam tvam khalitam sa pañña
translated: So you, wise one, have brought me, who have fallen,
back to life, who am without mantras.”
“I have given you the mantras through the Dhamma,
you have accepted them through the Dhamma;
I was pleased with you, and I gave you the boon,

original: Dhamme ṭhitaṁ taṁ na jaheyya manto.
analyzed: dhamme ṭhitam tam na jaheyya manto
translated: But you will not abandon the Dhamma in which you stand.
The fool who has obtained the boon,
Which is difficult to obtain in the human world,
Though he has obtained it, the fool, with little wisdom,

original: Vināsayī alikaṁ bhāsamāno.🔽Bālassa mūḷhassa akataññuno ca,
analyzed: vināsayī alikam bhāsamānaḥ  bālassa mūḷhassa a kataññuno ca
translated: Will destroy it, speaking falsely.🔽For the fool, the deluded one, the ungrateful one,
Who speaks falsely, who is undisciplined,
We do not give such a one the boon,

original: Kuto mantā gaccha na mayha ruccasī”ti.
analyzed: kutas mantā gaccha na mayha ruccasi iti
translated: Where are the boons? Go away, you are not pleasing to me.”
The Birth Story of Amba, the first.
